author: @horizonfios

text:
¬†@horizonfios¬† the shortest aging is 12 months, anything less than that cannot be considered parmesan. The most common aging in italy is 24 months i think. Other agings are 30 and 36 months. Some parmesans are aged till 48 or even 72 months, but it's rare. Of course, the longer the aging, the pricier and tastier is the cheese.
One last thing: it should be called Parmigiano Reggiano (or simply Parmigiano) because "parmesan" can be mistaken with the american version which tastes different and has different regulations in the production

text: OK, I'm going to stand up for the traditionalists here.  OK, that was quick. Sitting down now.  ;)  Jokes aside, there is room and need for both.  Of course experimentation is important, and making a pesto-like sauce from these ingredients is marvelous fun that leads to discovery, and Bottura knows how to make it good, not just a mishmash.  On the other hand, without the 'uptight assholes', we would have been overrun by industrial imitations of all the important ingredients.  Because of the 'elitist pedants', we know what Parmigiano Reggiano -- and a hundred others -- is supposed to taste like; it's not a taste in a vacuum, but something that is adjusted to work in the various local dishes, just as local wines are made to match the local ingredients.  I'm very happy over here in the US to know that I can get 'the real thing' and make the dishes that inspired generations of cooks.  It's frankly depressing to see 100 recipes for "authentic pesto" and see 90% of them using tools and ingredients and techniques that aren't at all what made pesto inspirational in the first place.  So, bravo to the experimentalists, and 'thank you' to the obsessive traditionalists.  We benefit greatly from both.
author: @ericpmoss

text:
fabio, Thanks for the chuckles....lighten up before you give yourself a stroke. A friend of mine who's family emigrated to Canada when he was very young in the 1950's were extremely poor. He told how bad it was because of shortness of money his father would scrounge around behind the slaughter house for chicken feet or any other tossed out meat he could find. I'm sure he would have gladly eaten pesto with breadcrumbs if it was offered to him.
Traditional recipes are peasant food which is why I shared the above story.....so don't get on your high horse mocking one of the best chef's in the world.

text:
For not Italian people: Forget about the salty Italians here, they're just ignorants and misunderstanding completely the point of the recipe. Also, there is no "traditional" pesto, in Italy we have all kinds of pesto and the only things that they have in common are some steps of the preparation and the texture. You could literally do pesto with almost every vegetable you can imagine. This is a good pesto and a very good way of using ingredients that would've gotten wasted. (Sorry if I made some grammar mistake)

Per gli italiani: Mi spiegate quando ha detto che avrebbe fatto un pesto alla genovese? Se usi il basilico non stai necessariamente facendo un pesto alla genovese, cos√¨ come se usi lo zafferano non stai necessariamente facendo un risotto alla milanese. Ha fatto un pesto a modo suo, dando a questi ragazzi degli spunti sulla preparazione e sul non sprecare ci√≤ che si ha in casa.

text: Chlorophyll oxidates when exposed to open air. So, when you cut or cook green herbs or vegetables, you basically expose the pigment to oxidation, that darkens its green colour. Cold helps slowing down the oxidation process, so using ice is a trick that chefs use to keep the food of its natural green colour. It doesn't affect the taste, just the appearance. Usually they cook green veggies (like cabbage, broccoli, ecc) in boiling water and then put them directly in an ice bowl, to keep them of a super-flashy green and not a dark turned-off green. Source: My Italian blood
author: @HistiPazzi

text: Chlorophyll oxidates when exposed to open air. So, when you cut or cook green herbs or vegetables, you basically expose the pigment to oxidation, that darkens its green colour. Cold helps slowing down the oxidation process, so using ice is a trick that chefs use to keep the food of its natural green colour. It doesn't affect the taste, just the appearance. Usually they cook green veggies (like cabbage, broccoli, ecc) in boiling water and then put them directly in an ice bowl, to keep them of a super-flashy green and not a dark turned-off green. Source: My Italian blood

text:
¬†@rhebersonbritto1344¬† The word "pesto" came from the verb "pestare" (in English, to grind or to pound). There are many varieties of pesto, but the most famous one is Pesto alla Genovese (from Genova).

So pesto can be anything, really. Pesto alla Genovese, on the other hand, is a specific traditional recipe.
Much like with lasagne alla bolognese.
Lasagne is the layer of pasta. Therefore, you can make lasagne with anything: pesto, vegetables, tofu, whatever.
Lasagne alla bolognese? That's another traditional and specific recipe.

Also, why do you assume that I represent the whole Italian population? To be honest, I don't care if the rest of the world changes pizza, as long as people keep in mind the original recipe.
I am aware of the many variations of pizza and I am glad it is so well-known and appreciated all throughout the globe, so much that people were inspired to try new things according to their preferences and culture.

text:
Italians indeed are really grumpy about traditional food making. That doesn't mean they are always wrong. Sometimes we are just bitching about some method that can actually be changed just like pesto, sometimes we are impotent spectators of the abuse of our food. The one-pot-pasta, for example, is often a heresy. There are some recipes that contemplate cooking pasta in the same pot as the sauce (look at "pasta e fagioli" or "pasta patate e provola"), but some steps have to be followed in the making and the sauce has to be very thick and not watery. This is because cooking it the right way is not only very simple, it's also fundamental as the pasta won't absorb the salty water and in the end the dish will be much lighter, healthier and more digestible. The solution is reading the advices and decide yourself if they make sense or not :)


And rocket salad is also a fantastic pesto ingredient.

text: Well, I guess he never specified that he would be making a classic pesto Genovese, so there's no reason to fault his recipe without even trying it. I recall reading a piece about pesto in which this old school Italian chef in Genoa said, "pesto is the way you make pesto". Basically, he didn't care about purism. Before the automobile and produce deliveries, pesto was made with what you had, and that wasn't always basil, pine nuts, and parmigiano-reggiano.

text: Hello i am writing from Genova.  I am sure that the old chef meant that every family here has a different way to make pesto. Pesto without specification Is not a recipe but kind of a method.  Recipes are like Pesto Genovese, Pesto Siciliano (totally different ingredients).  Or your special kind of recipe for a new pesto, if you have enough competence about relationship between ingredients in classic pestos recipes.

text: ‚Äã¬†@BRACALONEBORDINTEAM¬† totally agree with you, the blender can heat the sauce making it more bitter (there are solutions to this problem, ie. keeping all the ingredients in the fridge till the last second). But let's be clear: this is NOT the original pesto recipe. This is a brilliant waste-less pesto sauce recipe made by the best cook in the world, but it's not the original recipe: he swapped pine nuts with breadcrumbs, he didn't mention the pecorino (it should be at least 50/50 with parmigiano), he didn't use Pra basil (he explicitly said he was using "ugly basil"), I didn't see any garlic, he added fresh tomatoes, sugar, CRESCIONE! Anyway, I'm not criticizing him by any means (i'm not crazy), I would eat that pasta every day of my life. It was just to point out that the original genovese pesto recipe is different from this one. Which is not WRONG, BAD, or anything else. Just DIFFERENT.

text: ¬†@hunga.b¬† my friend, don't judge all the Italians and the all Italian culture from just one person. Bottura is one of the best chef in the world and even in his mother country, is been criticized for his cuisine. Pesto is a concept, a procedure, an idea. It's like saying hummus. Can be done using different ingredients because the technique, in this case, is more important than the most known version of it. In this video especially, the message is to show how the technique of pesto is perfect as a way to don't waste food and ingredients that usually are discarded. This concept is behind his last book and project. And please, honestly, someone in love with food, cuisine and cooking is always an open minded person. Always. So if you want to know the real Italian food culture, spend your time with the right people.
